sections.title: Custom occlusal splints to protect teeth and joints
sections.body: Night guards and occlusal splints are custom appliances designed to protect teeth and help manage bite-related strain. They are often used for grinding/clenching, tooth wear, fracture risk or jaw discomfort. We assess how your teeth meet, where forces concentrate and whether your symptoms suggest muscle overload or joint irritation. The appliance is then designed to fit comfortably and distribute forces more evenly. Splints don’t “cure” bruxism, but they can reduce damage and improve comfort while we monitor the situation. We’ll also explain care, expected adaptation time and when adjustments are needed.
bullets: Planned for clenching, grinding, and tooth wear
Choice of lab-made or 3D printed splints
Guided by your bite, comfort, and longevity goals

sections.title: Tailored protection for clenching and grinding
sections.body: Every occlusal splint is custom-made from your bite records to reduce tooth wear, ease muscle strain, and protect dental work. Materials and thickness are selected to balance comfort with the support you need overnight.
bullets: Covers the biting surfaces to distribute forces
Designed to reduce jaw tension and protect restorations
Adjustable fit to keep speech and breathing comfortable

sections.title: Measure your bite before prescribing
sections.body: We review your history, check jaw muscles and joints, and map tooth wear. Digital scans or impressions capture your bite so we can plan splint thickness, coverage, and occlusal contacts that feel balanced.
bullets: Examination of wear facets, mobility, and existing restorations
Bite analysis to see how your teeth meet and slide
Records taken for precise design and future reviews
Discussion of habits, posture, and sleep quality that affect clenching

sections.title: Splints prescribed by clinicians experienced in occlusal care
sections.body: We assess joint health, muscle tension, and tooth wear patterns before prescribing a splint. Bite records and digital scans guide thickness, contact points, and material choice to protect both natural teeth and existing restorations.

Design aims for even contact and smooth guidance

Follow-up adjustments scheduled to refine comfort

faqs.question: Who should consider an occlusal splint?
faqs.answer: They are recommended for patients with clenching, grinding, headaches from jaw tension, or restorations that need protection. We confirm suitability after examining your bite and joints.

faqs.question: Are there alternatives if I do not want a splint?
faqs.answer: Management may include exercises, habit coaching, or muscle therapies, but a splint is often the safest way to protect teeth and dental work from night-time forces. We will outline all options.

faqs.question: How long will my splint last?
faqs.answer: Durability depends on grinding forces, material choice, and care. We advise expected replacement intervals and check fit at reviews so we can refresh before wear reduces protection.

faqs.question: How do I look after the splint?
faqs.answer: Rinse and brush it gently after use, store it in a ventilated case, and avoid heat. Bring it to appointments so we can clean and adjust it, especially if your bite changes.

faqs.question: What are the risks or limitations?
faqs.answer: Splints can feel tight or cause tenderness if contacts are uneven; adjustments resolve this. Wear or cracks may occur with heavy grinding, so periodic review is important.

faqs.question: How are night guards priced?
faqs.answer: Fees reflect the material, lab or in-house production, and the complexity of your bite. We provide a written estimate and discuss phased care if repairs or replacements are anticipated.

faqs.question: Will it affect speech or breathing?
faqs.answer: Most people adapt quickly. We refine the fit and thickness to keep speech clear and breathing unobstructed.
